title: Bicameral
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Terminology](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Terminology) : Bicameral**

In typography, the term bicameral refers to [Alphabets](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Alphabets) which are made up of an [upper](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Upper%20Case) and [lower case](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/lower%20case). These alphabets include the [Greek](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Greek), [Roman](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Roman), [Armenian](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Armenian) and [Cyrillic](http://web.archive.org/web/20141110021142/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Cyrillic) alphabets.
author: hrant
